source:
In real-world applications, the noise is always present in the measured data. The noise can be due to various reasons such as the sensor noise, the environmental noise, the quantization noise, etc. The noise can be modeled as a random process. The package implements various type of noise in order to cover a wide range of practical situations.

## Additive Gaussian White noise

When a signal, real or complex, $x$ is corrupted by an additive Gaussian white noise $n$, the measured signal $y$ can be written as:
$$
    y = x + n
$$
where $n \sim \mathcal{N}(n| 0, \sigma^2)$

::: {.api}
**agwn**
#| echo: false
@doc agwn

data.text/plain:
[36magwn(x, snr_dB; rst = true)[39m

  Adds a Gaussian White Noise (AGWN) to a signal [36mx[39m with a given SNR.

  [1mInputs[22m

    [34m• [39m [36mx[39m: Signal (Real or Complex)
    [34m• [39m [36msnr_dB[39m: signal to noise ratio [dB]
    [34m• [39m [36mrst[39m: Reset the random number generator - Bool

  [1mOutput[22m

    [34m• [39m [36my[39m: Noisy signal
data.text/markdown:
```julia
agwn(x, snr_dB; rst = true)
```

Adds a Gaussian White Noise (AGWN) to a signal `x` with a given SNR.

**Inputs**

  * `x`: Signal (Real or Complex)
  * `snr_dB`: signal to noise ratio [dB]
  * `rst`: Reset the random number generator - Bool

**Output**

  * `y`: Noisy signal
data.text/html:
agwn(x, snr_dB; rst = true)

Adds a Gaussian White Noise (AGWN) to a signal x with a given SNR.

Inputs

  • x: Signal (Real or Complex)

  • snr_dB: signal to noise ratio [dB]

  • rst: Reset the random number generator - Bool

Output

  • y: Noisy signal

source:
#| output: false

# Noiseless signal
Δt = 1e-4
t = 0:Δt:1
x = sin.(2π*5*t)

# Signal to noise ratio
snr_dB = 25.

# Noisy signal
y = agwn(x, snr_dB)

#| echo: false

fig = Figure()
ax = Axis(fig[1, 1],
          xlabel = "Time (s)",
          ylabel = "Signal",
          title = "Additive Gaussian White Noise")
lines!(ax, t, y, label = "Original signal")
lines!(ax, t, x, color = :red, label = "Noisy signal")
Legend(fig[1, 2], ax)
display(fig);

## Additive Colored noise

When a signal, real or complex, $x$ is corrupted by an additive colored noise $n$, the measured signal $y$ can be written as:
$$
    y = x + n,
$$
where $n$ is a colored noise defined as in [Excitation models - Colored noise](https://maucejo.github.io/StructuralVibration.jl/models/excitation.html#sec-colored-noise).

::: {.api}
**acn - Real signal**
#| echo: false
@doc acn(x::VecOrMat{Float64}, snr_dB, fs, color = :pink; band_freq = Float64[], rst = true)

data.text/plain:
[36macn(x, snr_dB, fs, color = :pink; band_freq = Float64[], rst = true)[39m

  Adds a complex Colored Noise (ACN) to a signal [36mx[39m with a given SNR

  [1mInputs[22m

    [34m• [39m [36mx[39m: Signal
    [34m• [39m [36msnr_dB[39m: Signal to noise ratio [dB]
    [34m• [39m [36mfs[39m: Sampling frequency [Hz]
    [34m• [39m [36mcolor[39m: Color of the noise
       
       [34m• [39m [36m:white[39m
       [34m• [39m [36m:pink[39m (default)
       [34m• [39m [36m:blue[39m
       [34m• [39m [36m:brown[39m
       [34m• [39m [36m:purple[39m
    [34m• [39m [36mband_freq[39m: Frequencies used to defined the bandpass filter applied
       to the colored noise
    [34m• [39m [36mrst[39m: Reset the random number generator

  [1mOutput[22m

    [34m• [39m [36my[39m: Noisy signal
data.text/markdown:
```julia
acn(x, snr_dB, fs, color = :pink; band_freq = Float64[], rst = true)
```

Adds a complex Colored Noise (ACN) to a signal `x` with a given SNR

**Inputs**

  * `x`: Signal
  * `snr_dB`: Signal to noise ratio [dB]
  * `fs`: Sampling frequency [Hz]
  * `color`: Color of the noise

      * `:white`
      * `:pink` (default)
      * `:blue`
      * `:brown`
      * `:purple`
  * `band_freq`: Frequencies used to defined the bandpass filter applied to the colored noise
  * `rst`: Reset the random number generator

**Output**

  * `y`: Noisy signal

#| output: false

# Noiseless signal
Δt = 1e-4
fs = 1/Δt
t = 0:Δt:1
x = sin.(2π*5*t)

# Signal to noise ratio
snr_dB = 25.

# Noisy signal
y = acn(x, snr_dB, fs, :blue)

#| echo: false

fig = Figure()
ax = Axis(fig[1, 1],
          xlabel = "Time (s)",
          ylabel = "Signal",
          title = "Additive Colored Noise")
lines!(ax, t, y, label = "Original signal")
lines!(ax, t, x, color = :red, label = "Noisy signal")
Legend(fig[1, 2], ax)
display(fig);

## Multiplicative Gaussian White noise

When a signal, real or complex, $x$ is corrupted by a multiplicative Gaussian white noise $n$, the measured signal $y$ can be written as:
$$
    y = (1 + n)x
$$

::: {.api}
**mgwn**
#| echo: false
@doc mgwn

## Mixed noise

When a signal, real or complex, $x$ is corrupted by a mixed noise $n$, the measured signal $y$ can be written as:
$$
    y = (1 + n_m)x + n_a
$$
where $n_m$ is a multiplicative Gaussian white noise and $n_a$ is an additive Gaussian white noise.

::: {.api}
**mixed_noise**
#| echo: false
@doc mixed_noise

data.text/plain:
[36mmixed_noise(x, snr_dB; rst = true)[39m

  Adds both additive and multiplicative Gaussian White Noise to a signal [36mx[39m
  with a given SNR

  [1mInputs[22m

    [34m• [39m [36mx[39m: Signal
    [34m• [39m [36msnr_dB[39m: Signal to noise ratio [dB]
    [34m• [39m [36mrst[39m: Reset the random number generator

  [1mOutput[22m

    [34m• [39m [36my[39m: Noisy signal

```julia
mixed_noise(x, snr_dB; rst = true)
```

**Output**
